questions.text:
Arrange lung hilar structures from anterior to posterior:

 

1. Primary bronchus

2. Bronchial artery

3. Pulmonary vein

4. Pulmonary artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3, 4, 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Lung hilar structures are arranged from the anterior to posterior in the order:

 

  • Pulmonary vein
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Primary bronchus
  • Bronchial artery

 

The superior vena cava and right atrium are seen in front of the right root and terminal part of the azygos vein superiorly. The hilar structures are arranged from the superior to inferior as:

 

  • Superior lobar bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A boy presents with pallor and lymphadenopathy; the X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following drug is not used for the management of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine

 

  • The X-ray of the skull is showing circumscribed punched out lesions in the skull of a boy whose history reveals the presence of pallor and lymphadenopathy. This is suggestive of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis.
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare disease in which an excess of immature Langerhans cells (a type of white blood cell) accumulates in various parts of the body, leading to tissue damage and dysfunction.
  • The treatment of LCH depends on the severity and extent of the disease, as well as the age and overall health of the patient. Some cases of LCH can go away on their own, while others require treatment.

 

The main treatment options for LCH include:

 

1. Observation: In some cases, particularly in mild cases that only involve one or a few areas of the body, doctors may recommend monitoring the disease closely without any treatment. The goal is to watch for any changes or progression of the disease and intervene if necessary.

 

2. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy drugs are used to kill the abnormal Langerhans cells and control the disease. Some commonly used chemotherapy drugs for LCH include:

 

  • Vinblastine: Vinblastine is a chemotherapy drug that is often used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children. It works by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells. Vincristine is not recommended for LCH.
  • Methotrexate: Methotrexate is another chemotherapy drug that is commonly used to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.
  • Cladribine: Cladribine is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in more severe cases of LCH that do not respond to other treatments. It works by killing abnormal white blood cells.
  • Etoposide: Etoposide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the ability of abnormal cells to divide and grow.
  • Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

1. Steroids: Steroids are often used in conjunction with chemotherapy to help reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

 

2. Immunotherapy: Immunotherapy is a newer treatment option that involves using drugs that stimulate the immune system to attack and kill the abnormal cells.

 

3. Surgery: In some cases, surgery may be needed to remove damaged or diseased tissue, particularly if it is causing significant problems or pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Cyclophosphamide: Explanation: Cyclophosphamide is used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation: Methotrexate is used to treat LCH by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.

 

Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation: Vinblastine is commonly used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children, by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells.

 

Options D. Vincristine: Explanation: Vincristine is not recommended for LCH. Other chemotherapy drugs like vinblastine are preferred for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) is treated with various chemotherapy drugs, but vincristine is not typically used for this condition. Vinblastine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and other drugs are preferred for the management of LCH.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who had undergone an uneventful cataract surgery with intraocular lens implantation, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance in the operated eye, 36 hours post operatively. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Intravitreal antibiotics

 

The given image shows an inflamed eye with the presence hypopyon, which along with the history of a recent cataract surgery is suggestive of endophthalmitis.

 

Endophthalmitis is an inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball associated with exudate pouring in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

 

Modes of infection:

 

  1. Exogenous: following perforating injuries, perforation of infected corneal ulcers, or postoperative infections.
  2. Endogenous or metastatic endophthalmitis: occurs rarely through the bloodstream from some infected focus.
  3. Secondary infections from surrounding structures: rare.
  • Bacterial endophthalmitis: most frequent pathogens are gram-positive cocci, such as staphylococcus epidermidis and staphylococcus aureus.
  • Fungal endophthalmitis: comparatively rare, caused by aspergillus, fusarium, candida, etc.
  • Cardinal features: Pain, lid swelling, and decreased vision. Inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and hypopyon may also occur.
  • Treatment:
    • Intraocular fluid from anterior chamber or vitreous biopsy is sent for gram staining, KOH mount and culture.
    • Intravitreal injection of antibiotics is the primary therapy. Patient needs to be monitored daily to assess for resolution of clinical symptoms and repeat intravitreal antibiotic injections may be given as required.
    • Topical broadspectrum antibiotics, cycloplegics are also given simultaneously.
    • Oral steroids may be given.
    • Systemic antibiotics have no role in the management of endophthalmitis..

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous steroids: Not the primary treatment for endophthalmitis. Steroids may be used to reduce inflammation but not as the main intervention.

 

Option B. Intravenous antibiotics: Systemic antibiotics have limited effectiveness due to poor penetration into the eye.

 

Option C. Bandage and padding of the eye: Provides no therapeutic benefit for endophthalmitis and delays appropriate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intravitreal antibiotics are the primary treatment for endophthalmitis, a severe postoperative complication characterized by inflammation and hypopyon. Early and aggressive treatment is crucial to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: The most probable diagnosis for a young male presenting with Leucotrichia and lesions as depicted in the image is? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segmental vitiligo

 

Localized, unilateral depigmented macules can be seen in the image. This characteristic and a history of leukotrichia point to the diagnosis of segmental vitiligo in the patient.

 

Vitiligo happens because the basal layer lacks melanocytes due to autoimmune destruction by auto antibodies.

 

The gradual loss of melanocytes causes a localized depigmentation to take place.

 

It is categorized as:

 

  1. Segmental vitiligo: This form of vitiligo is characterized by unilateral depigmented macules in a dermatomal or segmental pattern. The presence of Leucotrichia (white or colorless hair) within the lesion is a strong clinical indicator of segmental vitiligo. The image shows a pattern consistent with segmental vitiligo.
  2. Non-segmental vitiligo: which appears as bilateral macules distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal vitiligo: This is characterized by one or more macules or patches in one area without any recognizable pattern as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option C. Piebaldism: It is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that is present at birth. The hallmark of piebaldism is a white forelock as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The distribution of lesions is usually symmetrical and remains stable throughout life, which differs from the presentation in the image.

 

Option D. Nevus depigmentosus: This is a congenital, stable hypopigmented patch that does not progress or change with time. Unlike vitiligo, it does not show Leucotrichia, and the lesion does not spread.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segmental vitiligo presents with one or more macules in a dermatomal or segmental pattern, often accompanied by Leucotrichia.

 

Ref - Rooks Textbook of dermatology 9th Edition page no 88.34

choices.text: There is hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus.
Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery
Supply is from posterior to anterior thoracic artery.
Collaterals develop to supply upper limb.

questions.text: A child presents with cold feet and a history of wearing socks even in the summers. On examination, lower limb pulses are diminished as compared to the radial pulse. Prominent radio femoral delay is present. What is the underlying condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery

 

The clinical presentation of cold feet, wearing socks even in summer, diminished lower limb pulses compared to radial pulses, and prominent radiofemoral delay is characteristic of coarctation of the aorta. This congenital condition is characterized by a narrowing (coarctation) of the aorta, typically just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery at the ductus arteriosus.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Coarctation of the Aorta: This condition results in the obstruction of blood flow, leading to higher blood pressure in the upper limbs and lower blood pressure in the lower limbs. The radiofemoral delay is a classic sign.
  • Location of Coarctation:
    • Postductal Coarctation (Adult Type): The constriction occurs distal to the ductus arteriosus. This type is more common and leads to the development of collateral circulation to bypass the obstruction.
    • Predductal Coarctation (Infantile Type): The constriction occurs proximal to the ductus arteriosus, leading to different clinical features and often presenting in infancy.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Cold feet and preference for wearing socks may be due to poor perfusion in the lower extremities.
    • Diminished lower limb pulses and radiofemoral delay are hallmark signs.
    • Hypertension in the upper extremities due to the coarctation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus: This condition does not cause radiofemoral delay or the constellation of symptoms seen in coarctation of the aorta.

 

Option C. Supply from posterior to anterior thoracic artery: This does not explain the clinical presentation, especially the radiofemoral delay.

 

Option D. Collaterals develop to supply upper limb: Collateral circulation is a compensatory mechanism that develops over time in coarctation of the aorta, primarily to supply blood to the lower extremities, not just the upper limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta typically presents with cold feet, diminished lower limb pulses, and radiofemoral delay due to a narrowing of the aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with symptoms of inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits. He was also not able to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

Explanation:

 

An ulnar nerve damage is suggested by the clinical scenario, which includes a positive card test and the inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits.

 

The most likely site of injury would thus be medial epicondyle: site C

 

 

Damage to the ulnar nerve at the medial epicondyle causes paralysis of the flexor carpi ulnaris (lack of ulnar deviation) and the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus (loss of distal interphalangeal joint flexion). Hypothenar paralysis (which causes atrophy) and sensory loss are the results. Moreover, the extensor digitorum and flexor digitorum superficialis (provided by the radial nerve and median nerve, respectively) continue to function. The third and fourth digits are therefore not completely paralysed. The palmar interossei's fragility, which causes a loss of adduction, is what causes the positive card test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head of the Humerus: Articulates with the shoulder joint. Injury here typically affects shoulder movement, not the distal functions like finger flexion or sensory issues associated with the ulnar nerve.

 

Option B. Intertubercular Groove: Houses the tendon of the biceps brachii. Mainly affects movements related to the biceps muscle, not ulnar nerve functions.

 

Option D. Lateral Epicondyle: Attachment site for forearm extensor muscles. Primarily involved in conditions like lateral epicondylitis, which causes localized pain rather than the broader sensory and motor deficits seen in ulnar nerve damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulnar nerve branches and supply:

 

 

Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs cause visual problems as an adverse effect? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is the anti-tubercular drug that can cause visual problems as an adverse effect. It is known for its potential to lead to optic neuritis, which can result in changes in visual acuity and color vision. Monitoring of vision is important during the use of ethambutol, and if visual disturbances occur, the drug may need to be discontinued to prevent further optic nerve damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is not typically associated with visual problems as an adverse effect.

 

Option B. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is not known to cause visual problems. However, it is associated with hepatotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy as potential adverse effects.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is not commonly associated with visual problems as an adverse effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is the anti-tubercular drug known for its association with visual problems. It can cause optic neuritis and changes in color vision, which may be reversible upon discontinuation of the drug.

questions.text: An infertile patient came with a history of sinus inversus, sinusitis, and pulmonary infection. Which syndrome is likely to occur? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

 

Kartagener syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the triad of situs inversus (reversed positioning of the internal organs), chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis (irreversible dilation of the bronchi).

 

The clinical features described in the question, including sinus inversus, sinusitis, and pulmonary infection (suggestive of bronchiectasis), are characteristic of Kartagener syndrome.

 

 

Kartagener syndrome is a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), a genetic condition in which the cilia (hair-like structures responsible for movement) are dysfunctional or immotile. This leads to impaired mucociliary clearance, resulting in recurrent respiratory infections, sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kallaman syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (delayed or absent puberty) and anosmia (lack of sense of smell), but it is not associated with the clinical features mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Although cystic fibrosis can lead to bronchiectasis, it is not typically associated with situs inversus or sinusitis as prominent features.

 

Option D. Samter syndrome: This is a triad of asthma, nasal polyps, and sensitivity to aspirin and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). It does not involve situs inversus or the clinical presentation described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis is characteristic of Kartagener syndrome, which is a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) resulting from dysfunctional cilia.

questions.text: Image of a patient with large ulcerated breast cancer with liver metastasis. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Simple mastectomy

 

The patient in the image has a large ulcerated breast tumor with confirmed liver metastasis, classifying the cancer as stage IV (T4, M1). In cases of stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, the primary goal of management shifts from curative to palliative care, focusing on improving quality of life and managing symptoms.

For patients with large ulcerated tumors, palliative simple mastectomy may be considered to alleviate symptoms like pain, ulceration, discharge, or infection, which can significantly impact the patient’s quality of life. This procedure is not intended to cure but to provide local control of the tumor and improve comfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRM (Modified Radical Mastectomy): This is a more aggressive surgical approach that involves removal of the breast tissue along with axillary lymph nodes. It is typically reserved for curative intent in earlier stages of breast cancer without distant metastasis. It is not appropriate for palliation in stage IV disease with liver metastasis.

 

Option C. Radical mastectomy: This involves removal of the entire breast, underlying chest muscles, and axillary lymph nodes. This extensive procedure is rarely performed today and is not suitable for palliative care in metastatic disease due to its high morbidity without a survival benefit.

 

Option D. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is used in locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) to shrink tumors before surgery, but in the presence of distant metastasis (M1), systemic chemotherapy alone would be preferred for palliative purposes. Surgery would only follow if there was a significant symptomatic tumor burden requiring local control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, such as liver metastasis, the primary focus is on palliation. Simple mastectomy may be performed to manage symptoms from a large ulcerated tumor, but more extensive surgeries or curative approaches are not indicated.

questions.text: Calculate the median from the given set of observations: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 4, 8. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4.5


The median is the middle value of a data set when arranged in ascending order. For an even number of observations, the median is found by taking the average of the two middle numbers. In this set, the values in ascending order are: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8. Since there are 8 values (an even number), the two middle values are 4 and 5. The median is calculated by averaging these two values:

 

Median = (4+5)/2 = 4.5

 

Educational Objective:
 

For an even number of observations, the median is the average of the two middle values when the data set is arranged in ascending order.

choices.text: Remove placenta and reposition the uterus
Put uterus inside without removing the placenta
Shift to OT and insert the uterus back

questions.text: A patient has just delivered a full-term baby and developed uterine inversion with the placenta still attached. What is the immediate next step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Put uterus inside without removing the placenta

 

Immediate management of uterine inversion involves repositioning the uterus before removing the placenta to prevent severe bleeding and shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to massive hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Shift to OT and insert the uterus back: Immediate manual repositioning is crucial before shifting to an operating theatre.

 

Option D. Start Oxytocin: Oxytocin is used after the uterus is repositioned to encourage contraction, not before.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of uterine inversion, the uterus should be repositioned with the placenta still attached to avoid significant bleeding, followed by medical management for uterine contraction.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. A histology image is shown below. What can be the diagnosis for this patient?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schwannoma

 

The given clinical scenario and histology image showing Verocay bodies are suggestive of Schwannoma /Acoustic neuroma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibroma is a benign tumor that develops along nerve cells. Histology image shows wreath like multinucleated giant cells.

 

 

Option B. Leiomyoma on histology shows well-differentiated, regular, spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with hyalinization.

 

 

Option D. Rhabdomyoma on microscopy shows enlarged myocytes with abundant glycogen. Post-processing, glycogen content gets reduced and look like thin strands.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannoma is a benign tumor often associated with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, diagnosed via characteristic histological patterns and confirmed with MRI. It requires careful management, sometimes involving advanced surgical techniques such as Gamma Knife surgery.

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is found to be associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bitot’s spots

 

Vitamin A deficiency is a significant public health issue, especially in developing countries, and it is associated with various ocular manifestations collectively known as xerophthalmia. One of the most specific and classic signs of Vitamin A deficiency is the presence of Bitot’s spots. These are foamy, whitish accumulations on the conjunctiva, typically located on the temporal side of the eye. They are caused by the buildup of keratin due to the lack of Vitamin A, which is essential for maintaining the health of the conjunctiva and cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: This is a common, benign, yellowish growth on the conjunctiva that is unrelated to Vitamin A deficiency. It is associated with aging and UV exposure.

 

Option C. Pterygium: This is a growth of fleshy tissue that may extend onto the cornea. It is linked to UV exposure and chronic irritation but is not associated with Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option D. Stocker's line: This is an iron deposit line seen at the leading edge of a pterygium and is not related to Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WHO Classification of Xerophthalmia

choices.text: 200 mg

questions.text: The maximum dose of PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 mg

 

Explanation:

 

Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF2α), also known as carboprost, is used for the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony. The therapeutic regimen and maximum dosage are crucial for effective management and patient safety.

 

  • Dose and Administration: The approved dose for treating uterine atony with PGF2α is 0.25 mg administered intramuscularly (IM).
  • Maximum Dose: The maximum cumulative dose is 2 mg. This is achieved by administering a total of 8 doses of 0.25 mg each.
  • Dosing Interval: These doses can be repeated at intervals of 15 to 90 minutes, depending on the clinical response and the patient's condition.

 

Contraindications

 

  • Bronchial Asthma: PGF2α can cause bronchoconstriction, which makes it contraindicated in patients with bronchial asthma.
  • Suspected Amniotic Fluid Embolism: Due to its potential to cause pulmonary airway and vascular constriction, it is also contraindicated in cases of suspected amniotic fluid embolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.25 mg: This is the single dose administered IM but not the cumulative maximum dose.

 

Option C. 20 mg: This dose is excessively high and not clinically recommended or safe.

 

Option D. 200 mg: This dose is not applicable for human use and is far beyond the safe and recommended limits.

 

Educational Objective

 

The maximum dose of prostaglandin F2 alpha in the management of postpartum hemorrhage is 2 mg, administered in 0.25 mg increments intramuscularly.

 

Ref: Page no 480, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: What is Edmond Locard known for? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Theory of exchange

 

Edmond Locard discovered two principles:

 

  1. Locard's Exchange Principle It states that whenever two bodies come in contact with each other, there is exchange of material between the two and so a criminal can be linked to crime
  2. Poroscopy: It is a method of identification through the comparison of the impressions of pores of sweat glands (present on palmar and plantar surfaces).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Study of fingerprints: Sir Francis Galton, developed the first classification system for fingerprints.

 

Option C. Stature estimation: This field involves estimating an individual's height from skeletal remains.

 

Option D. Forensic ballistics: This deals with the examination of firearms, bullets, and bullet impacts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Edmond Locard is best known for Locard's Exchange Principle, which states that whenever two bodies come into contact, there is an exchange of materials, thereby linking criminals to crime scenes.

questions.text: Identify what is depicted in the abdominal X-Ray? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ERCP and Bile duct

 

The abdominal X-ray KUB image shows a stent, specifically a double J (DJ) stent, commonly used in surgeries. The appearance and orientation of the stent are key to identifying its location. In this case, the stent is positioned vertically, which indicates it is in the bile duct. The bile duct runs vertically in the body, and a biliary stent used in procedures like ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) would also be oriented vertically. Conversely, a stent in the pancreatic duct would be oriented horizontally due to the anatomical layout of the pancreatic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ERCP and Pancreatic duct: A stent in the pancreatic duct would be oriented horizontally, not vertically, due to the horizontal course of the pancreatic duct. The given image shows a vertically oriented stent, which rules out this option.

 

Option C. Percutaneous transhepatic balloon catheter: This type of catheter would have a different appearance and is not typically placed in a vertical orientation like the stent shown in the X-ray.

 

Option D. Subcutaneous catheter: This type of catheter is used for different purposes and would not appear as a vertical stent in the abdominal X-ray. It also wouldn't be located in the bile duct or pancreatic duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vertical orientation of a stent on an abdominal X-ray is indicative of its placement in the bile duct, particularly in procedures involving ERCP.

questions.text: Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended to be done till what age of the child? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6 months

 

In India, exclusive breastfeeding is recommended until the baby is 6 months old, compared to 4 months in developed countries.

 

Breastfeeding should continue until the child is 2 years old in India and 1 year in developed countries.

 

Points to remember:

 

  • Breast milk provides about 65 kilocalories and 0.9 to 1.1 grams of protein per 100 ml.
  • Rich in immunoglobulin A, crucial for the infant’s immune development, along with other immunoglobulins.
  • Contains essential fatty acids like docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and taurine, both important for brain development.
  • Higher levels of lactose, iron, and water in breast milk compared to cow's milk, with better calcium to phosphorus ratio.
  • Iron in breast milk has high absorption; though calcium is lower, its absorption is high.
  • Casein to whey ratio is less than 1, beneficial for infants.
  • Initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth: within one hour after vaginal delivery and four hours after cesarean section, ideally at the delivery table.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first 6 months of life to ensure the best possible health outcomes for the child.

questions.text: Which trisomy is suggested by karyotyping results showing chromosomal defects? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Edward syndrome

 

The karyotyping result showing an extra chromosome at the level of chromosome 18 indicates Trisomy 18, which is characteristic of Edward syndrome. Edward syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of all or part of an extra 18th chromosome. This condition leads to severe developmental delays, congenital heart defects, and other abnormalities. The karyotype typically shows three copies of chromosome 18 instead of the usual two.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome is not associated with trisomy. Instead, it is characterized by the presence of a single X chromosome (45,X) in females. It is a monosomy condition, not a trisomy.

 

Option C. Patau syndrome: Patau syndrome is associated with Trisomy 13, where there is an extra chromosome 13. The karyotype shows three copies of chromosome 13, not 18.

 

Option D. Down syndrome: Down syndrome is caused by Trisomy 21, characterized by an extra chromosome 21. The karyotype shows three copies of chromosome 21, not 18.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Edward syndrome is caused by Trisomy 18, where the karyotype reveals an extra chromosome 18. This distinguishes it from other chromosomal disorders such as Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) and Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13)

questions.text: As per WHO categorization of bioterrorism agents, Anthrax belongs to (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Category A

 

The WHO categorizes bioterrorism agents into three main categories based on their potential impact on public health and their ease of dissemination.

 

Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) is classified as a Category A agent, which includes the highest priority agents that pose the greatest risk to national security and public health.

 

Category A agents are easily disseminated or transmitted from person to person, cause high mortality rates, and have the potential for major public health impact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Category B: Includes agents that are moderately easy to disseminate and result in moderate morbidity rates and low mortality rates, require enhanced diagnostic capacity with enhanced surveillance.

 

Option C. Category C: Includes NEW emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of their availability, ease of production and dissemination, and potential for high morbidity and mortality rates.

 

Option D. Category D: Not a recognized category by WHO for bioterrorism agents.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Anthrax is the MC used bioterrorism agent
  • Small pox is the most dangerous bioterrorism agent
  • Botulism most lethal toxin wise bioterrorism agent

questions.text: Ammonia is transported from the brain to the liver in the form of which of the following amino acids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glutamine

 

Explanation

 

Ammonia is transported from the brain to the liver primarily in the form of glutamine.

This is because glutamine can safely carry ammonia through the bloodstream to the liver, where the urea cycle converts it into urea for excretion.

The liver's urea cycle is the primary site for detoxifying ammonia, a neurotoxic byproduct of amino acid metabolism.

Glutamine plays a crucial role in this process by acting as a carrier molecule that neutralizes ammonia, thus preventing its accumulation and potential toxicity in the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamate: While glutamate is involved in ammonia metabolism, it is not the primary transporter of ammonia from the brain to the liver. Instead, glutamate is often converted to glutamine for this purpose.

 

Option B. Alanine: Alanine transports ammonia primarily from muscle tissues to the liver. It is part of the glucose-alanine cycle, which helps in the conversion of pyruvate to glucose in the liver.

 

Option C. Glycine: Glycine does not play a significant role in ammonia transport from the brain to the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glutamine is the primary amino acid responsible for transporting ammonia from the brain to the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred drug for treatment of post-menopausal breast cancer? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anastrozole

 

Aromatase inhibitors like anastrozole and letrozole are  considered the preferred drugs for the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer in post-menopausal women whereas tamoxifen is considered drug of choice in pre-menopausal women. Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor whereas tamoxifen works as a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), both are effective in blocking the effects of estrogen on breast cancer cells. Methotrexate may be used in breast cancer treatment, however it is not a first line drug. On the other hand, raloxifene is a SERM used for treatment of osteoporosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a chemotherapy drug used in the treatment of various cancers, including some types of breast cancer. However, it is not typically the first-line choice for post-menopausal breast cancer.

 

Option B. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) primarily used for osteoporosis and the prevention of breast cancer, rather than its treatment.

 

Option C. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is a widely used medication for the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer in both pre-menopausal and post-menopausal women. It is often the preferred choice for breast cancer in pre-menopausal female.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor and is drug of choice for treatment of breast cancer (which is estrogen receptor positive) in post-menopausal females.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with substernal chest discomfort. On examination, he was hypotensive, drowsy, and had unequal pulses. Which of the following investigations would be the best in this situation to ascertain the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trans-esophageal echocardiography

 

The presentation of acute chest pain, hypotension, drowsiness, and unequal pulses strongly suggests aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate diagnosis and management.

 

Trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is highly sensitive and specific for diagnosing aortic dissection. It can be performed at the bedside, making it ideal for unstable patients. TEE provides detailed images of the aorta and can quickly confirm the presence of an intimal flap, a characteristic finding in aortic dissection.

 

If the patient has been stable, then preferred investigation of choice is CT angiography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CXR PA view: A chest X-ray (CXR) might show a widened mediastinum, which can be a clue to aortic dissection, but it is not definitive. It lacks the sensitivity and specificity needed for a rapid and accurate diagnosis in an emergency setting.

 

Option C. MRI: While MRI can provide excellent detail, it is not suitable for acutely unstable patients due to the time required for the scan and the need to transport the patient to the MRI suite. It is not practical in an emergency setting.

 

Option D. Troponin assay: Troponin assays are used to diagnose myocardial infarction, not aortic dissection. Although troponins can be elevated in some cases of aortic dissection, they do not provide definitive diagnostic information about the dissection itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of suspected aortic dissection, especially in an unstable patient, trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the best diagnostic tool due to its high sensitivity and ability to be performed at the bedside, providing rapid and accurate confirmation of the diagnosis.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿The entire life cycle takes about 15 days
﻿﻿﻿Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

questions.text: A 30-year-old female developed pruritic papules with excoriated plaques in the interdigital web spaces. Later the lesion spread to the groin and under-surface of the breasts. The lady gives a history of intense pruritus which is more severe at night. Given below is the organism responsible for this condition. Identify the wrong statement about the same? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

 

This statement is incorrect because it is the female mite, not the male, that burrows into the skin. The male mites mainly stay on the surface of the skin and do not create burrows like the females do.

 

The clinical background is probably suggestive Scabies. The given image depicts Itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. The female parasite burrows into the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and lays eggs in the burrow.

 

A single female may lay about 30 eggs at a rate of 2 to 3 per day, and ultimately dies at the end of the burrow.

 

The life cycle has 4 stages: Egg, Larva, Nymph, and Adult. The adult mites live for 1 to 2 months. 

 

Itching is a hypersensitivity reaction to the eggs and dead parasite in the epidermis.

 

Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Life history has 4 stages: The lifecycle of Sarcoptes scabiei consists of the egg, larva, nymph, and adult stages, correctly described in the statement.

 

Option B. Larvae have 3 pairs of legs: The larvae of the scabies mite indeed have three pairs of legs, distinguishing them from the adult mites.

 

Option C. The entire life cycle takes about 15 days: The lifecycle from egg to mature mite, under ideal conditions, typically spans around 15 days, making this statement accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The female Sarcoptes scabiei mite is responsible for burrowing into the skin and laying eggs, which leads to the intense itching and characteristic rash seen in scabies. Recognizing the specific behavior of the female mite in the transmission and lifecycle of scabies is crucial for effective diagnosis and management of the condition.

choices.text: It is exclusively given in the deltoid
Not given after 7 days of the 1st dose of the vaccine
If human RIG is unavailable, equine is preferred

questions.text: A physician is preparing to administer post-exposure prophylaxis for a patient who has been bitten by a potentially rabid animal. Which of the following statements about the administration of rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is INCORRECT? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) It is exclusively given in the deltoid

 

  • Dose of Human Rabies Immunoglobulin (HRIg): 20 IU/kg body weight
  • Dose of Equine Rabies Immunoglobulin (ERIg): 40 IU/kg body weight
  • RIg must be given as soon as possible
  • RIg is NOT recommended beyond the 7th day of starting first dose of vaccine
  • RIg must never be given Intravenously
  • Entire dose of RIg (or as much as possible) must be infiltrated around the wound(s) site(s).
  • Remaining dose, if any, must be given Intramuscularly in deltoid

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) should be infiltrated around the wound site and any remaining dose given intramuscularly, preferably in the deltoid, but it is not exclusively given in the deltoid.

questions.text: A person who at the time of commission of the offense was of unsound mind, is exempt if he didn't know the nature of the act or its consequences. This rule is known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McNaughton rule

 

The McNaughton rule, also known as the legal test or right-wrong test, is the standard used in India to determine criminal responsibility for individuals with mental illness. According to this rule, a person is exempt from criminal responsibility if, at the time of the commission of the offense, they were suffering from a mental disorder that rendered them incapable of understanding the nature of their act or knowing that it was wrong. This rule emphasizes the individual's ability to understand the act, rather than their ability to control their behavior.

 

The rule is codified in Indian law under Section 84 Indian Penal Code (IPC) (Now, 22 BNS) and has been the primary standard for assessing the criminal liability of mentally ill offenders in India. If a person can understand that their actions are wrong, they are held responsible; otherwise, they are not.

 

Additional Information

 

Various rules related to the criminal responsibility of mentally ill individuals:

 

  • McNaughten Rule: This is a legal test that focuses on whether the person knew right from wrong at the time of the offense. This is also referenced in Section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).
  • Irresistible Impulse Test: Indicates that a person is not responsible if they acted on an uncontrollable impulse despite knowing the act was wrong.
  • Durham Rule: A person is not criminally responsible if the unlawful act was the product of a mental disease or defect.
  • Currens Rule: States that a person is not responsible if they lacked the capacity to conform to the requirements of the law.
  • American Law of Institute Test: A person is not responsible if they lacked:
    • Adequate capacity to appreciate the criminality of their conduct due to a mental disease or defect (cognitive insanity).
    • Adequate capacity to conform their conduct to the requirements of law (volitional insanity).
  • Doctrine of Partial Responsibility: This implies that while a person may be responsible, their mental illness is considered as a mitigating factor, potentially leading to reduced culpability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Durham's rule: This rule states that an individual is not criminally responsible if their unlawful act was the product of mental disease or defect. It focuses on the presence of a mental disease or defect as the cause of the unlawful act, rather than the individual's understanding of the nature of the act.

 

Option C. Currens rule: This rule states that an individual is not criminally responsible if they lacked the capacity to conform their conduct to the requirements of the law due to mental illness. It emphasizes the individual's ability to conform their behavior to legal standards.

 

Option D. Irresistible impulse test: This test states that an individual is not criminally responsible if, due to mental illness, they were unable to control their actions or resist the impulse to commit the act, even if they understood the nature of the act and that it was wrong.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, the McNaughton rule is used to determine criminal responsibility for individuals with mental illness. According to this rule, a person is exempt from criminal responsibility if they were unable to understand the nature of their act or know that it was wrong due to their mental condition.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with a body weight of 15kg and height of 100cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 BSA

 

Step-by-Step Calculation

 

Step 1: Identify the appropriate k value

For a 4-year-old child: k = 0.413

 

Step 2: Apply the formula

eGFR = k × Height / Serum Creatinine

 

Step 3: Substitute values

eGFR = 0.413 × 100 / 1

 

Step 4: Calculate

eGFR = 41.3 / 1 = 41.3 ml/min/1.73 m²

 

Step 5: Round to nearest option

41.3 ≈ 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) in pediatric patients can be calculated using the Schwartz formula, which is widely used in clinical practice. The formula takes into account the patient's height and serum creatinine levels, along with a constant value that is adjusted for age and sex.

 

The modified Schwartz formula is most commonly used for this purpose. It is given as:

 

 

 

For children aged 1 to 16 years, the constant k is typically 0.413

 

Given the child's height of 100 cm and serum creatinine of 1 mg/dL:

 

 

 

The closest value provided in the options is 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA, which is therefore the correct answer

 

Understand and apply the Schwartz formula for estimating eGFR in pediatric patients based on height and serum creatinine levels.

choices.text: Previous manual removal of placenta

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered as a factor for a high-risk pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Previous manual removal of placenta

 

Explanation:

 

Previous manual removal of the placenta does not automatically categorize a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk. High-risk pregnancies are characterized by various factors that may complicate the pregnancy or pose risks to the mother and fetus. These factors include existing health conditions, certain lifestyle factors, age-related risks, and specific pregnancy conditions.

 

High-risk pregnancy factors according to the NIH include:

 

  1. Existing health conditions:
    • Hypertension
    • Diabetes
    • Autoimmune diseases
    • PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome)
    • Thyroid disorders
    • Obesity
    • HIV
    • Anemia
    • Uterine fibroids
  2. Age:
    • Adolescence
    • First-time pregnancy at age >35 years
  3. Lifestyle factors:
    • Alcohol consumption
    • Smoking
    • Drug use
  4. Pregnancy conditions:
    • Multiple pregnancy
    • Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)
    • Pre-eclampsia
    • Previous preterm birth
    • Congenital or chromosomal anomalies
    • Polyhydramnios or oligohydramnios
    • Rh iso-immunization
    • Antepartum hemorrhage
    • Fetal growth restriction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obesity: Obesity is a significant factor for a high-risk pregnancy as it is associated with various complications such as gestational diabetes, pre-eclampsia, and increased risk of cesarean delivery.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios, which is an excessive amount of amniotic fluid, can lead to complications such as preterm labor and fetal malformations, making it a high-risk condition.

 

Option C. Anemia: Anemia during pregnancy can affect the health of both the mother and the fetus, leading to conditions such as preterm birth and low birth weight, thus categorizing it as high-risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Previous manual removal of the placenta is not considered a factor for categorizing a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk.

 

Ref: https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/high-risk

questions.text: Case fatality rate of the disease rabies is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 100%.

 

Rabies is one of the deadliest infectious diseases, with a case fatality rate approaching 100%. This means that once clinical symptoms of rabies appear, the disease is almost always fatal, making it the highest fatality rate for any known disease.

 

The case fatality rate is calculated by dividing the number of deaths due to a disease by the number of diagnosed cases of that disease and then multiplying by 100 to express it as a percentage.

 

The reason rabies has such a high case fatality rate is due to the virus's effects on the central nervous system, leading to acute encephalitis (inflammation of the brain). Once symptoms develop, there is no effective treatment, and death usually occurs within days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Case fatality rate (CFR) is used to measure the virulence of organism or killing power of a disease.
  • CFR for COVID-19 and Chickenpox is about 1%.
  • Measles has a CFR of 3%.
  • Rabies has the highest CFR at nearly 100%, with no cure available once symptoms appear.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is brought to the ER in a state of unconsciousness. Her BP is 70/50 mm of Hg and her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of her condition? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synchronized cardioversion

 

Any hemodynamically unstable rhythm, requires synchronized cardioversion (Shock delivered in sync with R wave to prevent R-on-T phenomenon)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: AV Nodal blockers are used if hemodynamically stable.

 

Option B: Maximum of 30mg of adenosine can be tried if patient is Hemodynamically Stable.

 

Option C: Carotid massage is not recommended for hemodynamically unstable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the condition that does not lead to bilateral hydronephrosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retrocaval ureter

 

Retrocaval ureter is a rare congenital anomaly where the right ureter passes behind the inferior vena cava (IVC) and gets compressed, leading to right-sided hydronephrosis. This condition does not cause bilateral hydronephrosis because it only affects the right ureter.

 

Retrocaval ureter, also known as circumcaval ureter, is a condition where the right ureter passes behind the IVC, causing compression and right-sided hydronephrosis, but it does not affect the left ureter, thus not leading to bilateral hydronephrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phimosis: Phimosis, a condition where the foreskin cannot be fully retracted over the glans penis, can lead to urinary retention and subsequent bilateral hydronephrosis if severe and left untreated.

 

Option B. Urethral Stricture: A urethral stricture is a narrowing of the urethra which can obstruct urine flow and cause bilateral hydronephrosis if the obstruction is significant and near the bladder neck or urethra.

 

Option C. Posterior urethral valve: Posterior urethral valves are congenital obstructive membranes in the posterior male urethra. They cause significant obstruction, leading to bilateral hydronephrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retrocaval ureter is a condition that affects only the right ureter, leading to right-sided hydronephrosis and does not cause bilateral hydronephrosis.

choices.text: Impact of a semi sharp-edged object
Overstretching of skin and subcutaneous tissue
Tissue crushed between weapon and underlying bone

questions.text: A 30-year-old alcoholic comes to the casualty after being hurt in a fight with a stranger. A lacerated wound is seen over his skull. Which of the following is the correct mechanism of this lacerated wound? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tissue crushed between weapon and underlying bone

 

The laceration shown above is an incised looking lacerated wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shearing force: Shearing force typically causes a different type of laceration, not the incised-like laceration seen in the image.

 

Option B. Impact of a semi sharp-edged object: This might cause a different wound pattern, more akin to a cut or a clean incision rather than a laceration.

 

Option C. Overstretching of skin and subcutaneous tissue: This causes stretch lacerations, which do not match the appearance of the wound shown.

 

Educational objective

 

Classification of a Laceration:

 

  • Split laceration (incised-like laceration): When the skin is crushed between two hard objects.

  • Incised-looking lacerated wound It is seen where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue such as the scalp, forehead, shin.

  • Avulsed laceration: A lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues.

  • Tears: Tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue from localized impact

  • Stretch laceration: It occurs due to the over-stretching of the skin, beyond its elasticity.

  • Cut laceration: Injury by a heavy sharp-edged instrument like axe.

choices.text: Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is NOT used as a first line therapy for ADHD? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors

 

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is commonly treated with stimulant medications, which are the first line of treatment. The main drugs of choice include methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate, and dextroamphetamine. These medications work by increasing dopamine and norepinephrine levels in the brain, improving concentration and reducing impulsivity and hyperactivity.

 

Atomoxetine, although not a stimulant, is also used as a treatment option for ADHD. It works as a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and is considered a non-stimulant alternative, especially useful in patients who may not respond well to stimulants or who have contraindications.

 

Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), such as venlafaxine and duloxetine, are primarily used as antidepressants and are not typically used as first-line or preferred treatments for ADHD. These medications target different neurotransmitter systems and do not specifically address the core symptoms of ADHD as effectively as stimulants or atomoxetine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylphenidate: alpha agonist: This is incorrect because methylphenidate is a stimulant and a common first-line treatment for ADHD, although it is not an alpha agonist. It increases dopamine and norepinephrine activity in the brain.

 

Option B. Dexmethylphenidate or Dextroamphetamine: Dexmethylphenidate is a derivative of methylphenidate and is also a drug of choice for ADHD, working similarly to increase dopamine and norepinephrine levels.

 

Dextroamphetamine is a stimulant that is often used in the management of ADHD due to its efficacy in increasing dopamine and norepinephrine release, which helps in reducing ADHD symptoms.

 

Option C. Atomoxetine: antidepressant: Although it is referred to as an antidepressant, atomoxetine is actually a non-stimulant specifically approved for the treatment of ADHD, making it a valid option for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) are not the drugs of choice for ADHD, whereas stimulants like methylphenidate and dextroamphetamine, and non-stimulants like atomoxetine, are preferred treatments.

 

Remember -

 

  • Drugs used:
  • Methylphenidate: alpha agonist
  • Dx methylphenidate
  • Dextro amphetamine
  • Atomoxetine: antidepressant
  • Tricyclic antidepressants like
  • Imipramine
  • Clonidine, guanfacine

questions.text: In a suspected case of cholangitis in a 47-year-old woman, what other component besides abdominal pain does not comprise Reynold's pentad? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hematemesis

 

Hematemesis (vomiting of blood) is not a component of Reynold's pentad. Reynold's pentad includes: jaundice, fever, abdominal pain, altered sensorium, and hypotension. Hematemesis can be a symptom of various other gastrointestinal issues but is not typically associated with cholangitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Cholangitis is an infection of the common bile duct caused by obstruction and increased pressure due to CBD stones.
  2. The classical triad of cholangitis (Charcot) is fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice.
  3. If left untreated, cholangitis can progress to Reynold's pentad with hypotension and altered mental status due to sepsis.
  4. Abdominal ultrasound is used to diagnose biliary stones and bile duct dilatations in cholangitis.
  5. Treatment for cholangitis includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, rehydration, and biliary drainage using endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).
  6. Biliary stones are the primary cause of cholangitis and can be removed by endoscopic sphincterotomy during ERCP.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient is brought to the ER following a suspected stroke. The patient is unable to speak fluently, though he understands the given instructions. Which category of aphasia is most likely present in the patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Broca's aphasia

 

Explanation:

 

The patient in the question exhibits symptoms consistent with Broca's aphasia, also known as motor aphasia. In Broca's aphasia, the patient has difficulty with speech production and articulation but maintains relatively intact language comprehension. This is evident from the fact that the patient understands the given instructions but is unable to speak fluently.

 

Broca's area, located in the frontal lobe (Brodmann areas 44 and 45), is responsible for speech production and articulation. Damage to this area, often caused by a stroke, results in Broca's aphasia. Patients with Broca's aphasia struggle with fluent speech but can typically understand language, as the Wernicke's area remains unaffected.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's aphasia : This is a form of sensory aphasia where patients have difficulty understanding language but can produce fluent, albeit meaningless, speech. Wernicke’s area is located at the Posterior part of area no 22. This is associated with hearing loss.

 

Option C. Conduction aphasia : In this type of aphasia, the patient can understand and produce language, but there is a disconnect between the Wernicke's area and the Broca's area (Brodmann areas 39 and 40). This results in difficulty repeating words or phrases, which is not mentioned in the patient's case.

 

Option D. Global aphasia : This is a severe form of aphasia involving both Broca's and Wernicke's areas, leading to impairments in both language production and comprehension. The patient in the question does not exhibit signs of impaired comprehension, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca's aphasia, or motor aphasia, is characterized by difficulty in speech production and articulation while language comprehension remains relatively intact. It is caused by damage to Broca's area (Brodmann areas 44 and 45) in the frontal lobe, often due to a stroke.

questions.text: Methotrexate acts by inhibiting: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dihydrofolate reductase

 

Methotrexate is a chemotherapy agent and immune system suppressant. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. This enzyme is crucial for the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, a form of folic acid that is required for the synthesis of thymidylate, purines, and the amino acid methionine.

 

By inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, methotrexate effectively depletes the cell’s supply of tetrahydrofolate, which in turn inhibits DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis. This inhibition is particularly effective against rapidly dividing cells, which is why methotrexate is used in the treatment of certain cancers and autoimmune diseases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thymidylate synthetase: Thymidylate synthetase is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of thymidylate (dTMP) from deoxyuridylate (dUMP), which is necessary for DNA synthesis. This enzyme is inhibited by 5-Fluorouracil, not methotrexate.

 

Option B. DNA polymerase: DNA polymerase is an enzyme responsible for forming new copies of DNA, but methotrexate does not directly inhibit this enzyme. Inhibition of DNA polymerase would prevent DNA replication, but methotrexate acts upstream in the folate pathway.

 

Option C. RNA Polymerase: RNA polymerase is responsible for synthesizing RNA from a DNA template. Methotrexate does not inhibit RNA polymerase; instead, it inhibits the production of necessary components for DNA and RNA synthesis indirectly by depleting tetrahydrofolate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate acts by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, thereby preventing the synthesis of DNA, RNA, and proteins by depleting tetrahydrofolate.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arterial wall compliance

 

Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and it reflects the compliance (elasticity) of the arterial walls. In this scenario, the patient has a high systolic blood pressure and a normal diastolic blood pressure, resulting in an increased pulse pressure of 90 mm Hg (190 mm Hg - 100 mm Hg = 90 mm Hg).

 

Arterial wall compliance refers to the ability of the arteries to expand and contract with each heartbeat, which helps maintain a steady blood pressure. Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, which can cause an increase in systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial contractility: Incorrect. While myocardial contractility can influence blood pressure, it is not directly related to the increase in pulse pressure in this scenario.

 

Option B. Stroke volume: Incorrect. Stroke volume affects cardiac output and overall blood pressure but is not the primary factor in the increase in pulse pressure observed here.

 

Option D. Cardiac output: Incorrect. Cardiac output can affect overall blood pressure, but the specific increase in pulse pressure in this case is more closely linked to decreased arterial wall compliance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, resulting in higher systolic blood pressure and an increased pulse pressure, as observed in the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following supplement is required more for a lactating woman than the pregnant female? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Vitamin A


During lactation, the mother's body requires additional nutrients to support breast milk production, which provides all necessary nutrients for the growing infant. Some nutrient needs increase more during lactation than pregnancy.

 

Comparison of Nutritional Requirements:

 

Vitamin A:

Needed for:

  • Infant vision development
  • Immune function
  • Epithelial integrity

Significantly increased loss through breast milk

Hence, greater requirement in lactation than pregnancy

 

Others options:


B12, Calcium, and Thiamine requirements increase only slightly or remain the same.

Vitamin A shows the most significant increase.

 

Educational Objective: 

Vitamin A is required more for a lactating woman than a pregnant female. This increased need ensures that there is enough vitamin A in breast milk to support the baby's growth and development, particularly for their immune system and vision.

choices.text: Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days
Admit and observe
Follow-up with beta-HCG

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test came with complaints of lower abdominal pain, moderate bleeding PV. She was hemodynamically stable. On ultrasound, there was no gestational sac in the uterus. Ovaries were normal and no free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Follow-up with beta-HCG

 

The patient presents with symptoms that could indicate either an ectopic pregnancy or an early miscarriage. The absence of a gestational sac in the uterus on ultrasound at 6 weeks' gestation warrants further investigation to determine the location and viability of the pregnancy. The most appropriate next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Ectopic Pregnancy vs. Early Miscarriage: The differential diagnosis includes both ectopic pregnancy and early miscarriage.
  • Serial Beta-HCG Measurement: Beta-HCG levels typically double every 48-72 hours in a normal early intrauterine pregnancy. An abnormal rise or plateau in beta-HCG levels may indicate an ectopic pregnancy or a failing pregnancy.
  • Ultrasound Follow-up: In combination with beta-HCG monitoring, follow-up ultrasounds can help determine if a gestational sac becomes visible in the uterus or elsewhere.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days: Declaring a complete abortion without further investigation is premature and may miss an ectopic pregnancy, which can have serious complications.

 

Option B. Admit and observe: While observation is important, serial beta-HCG levels provide critical information that can guide further management decisions.

 

Option C. Diagnostic laparoscopy: This is an invasive procedure and is not the first step in stable patients without definitive evidence of ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, a positive pregnancy test, and no gestational sac visible on ultrasound, the next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels to differentiate between an early intrauterine pregnancy, an ectopic pregnancy, and a miscarriage.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 356

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presented with chest pain. In an angiogram, her left circumflex artery was found to be stenosed, and a stent was inserted. Her current medications include ASA 75mg OD, atenolol 50mg BID, lovastatin, and lisinopril. What should be done in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Add P2Y12 receptor inhibitor

 

After stent placement, it is crucial to prevent stent thrombosis, which can be life-threatening. Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) is the standard of care in this scenario. DAPT includes aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor). These medications work synergistically to inhibit platelet aggregation and prevent thrombus formation within the stent.

 

The patient is already on aspirin 75 mg daily, so the addition of a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor is necessary to complete the DAPT regimen. This combination has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of stent thrombosis and other cardiovascular events after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement.

 

Guidelines on the duration of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) –

 

  • Drug-Eluting Stents (DES): A minimum of 6 months of DAPT is recommended. This therapy usually involves the use of aspirin combined with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel) to prevent clot formation around the new stent.
  • Bare Metal Stents (BMS): At least 1 month of DAPT is required. Although the duration is shorter than that for DES, it's crucial for preventing early stent thrombosis.
  • Stents Inserted for Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): If a stent is inserted as part of treatment for ACS, the recommended minimum duration of DAPT extends to 12 months. This extended period helps manage the higher risk of thrombosis and other complications associated with ACS.
  • Current Patient Situation: Ongoing Medication: The patient is already on aspirin. A P2Y12 receptor inhibitor needs to be added to the regimen to complete the DAPT, ensuring optimal protection against clotting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase Aspirin dose: Increasing the aspirin dose does not provide additional benefit in preventing stent thrombosis and is not recommended as part of DAPT. The current dose of 75 mg is adequate when combined with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor.

 

Option B. Increase atenolol dose: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is used for managing hypertension and angina but does not prevent stent thrombosis. Increasing its dose does not address the immediate need for antiplatelet therapy post-stent placement.

 

Option C. Add a Long-Acting Nitrate: Long-acting nitrates can help manage angina symptoms but do not prevent stent thrombosis. They are not part of the recommended therapy to prevent thrombotic complications after stent placement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After stent placement, dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor) is essential to prevent stent thrombosis and ensure optimal patient outcomes.

questions.text: Following delivery of a preterm baby, the baby died in the NICU despite all efforts. What medication would be given to the mother for reducing breast tenderness? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cabergoline

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist and is the drug of choice for suppressing lactation. It works by inhibiting prolactin secretion from the pituitary gland, which reduces milk production and alleviates breast engorgement and tenderness.

 

Cabergoline is preferred because it is effective, has a favorable side effect profile, and is well-tolerated by most patients. It is also used in conditions like galactorrhea where suppression of lactation is desired.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Dopamine: While dopamine agonists like cabergoline work to suppress prolactin, dopamine itself is not used directly for this purpose in clinical settings. Cabergoline, being a dopamine agonist, is more specifically tailored for this function.

 

Option C. Ergot alkaloids: Ergot alkaloids have some dopamine agonist activity and can suppress prolactin, but they are not the drug of choice for lactation suppression due to their side effects and less favorable risk profile compared to cabergoline.

 

Option D. Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analog used to prevent gastric ulcers, induce labor, and manage postpartum hemorrhage, but it has no role in lactation suppression or reducing breast tenderness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cabergoline is the preferred medication for suppressing lactation and reducing breast tenderness in cases where breastfeeding is not desired or possible, such as after neonatal death
